snippet: The turnabout comes after a day of embarrassing criticism over the government’s assertion that the dissident Chinese artist had lied on his application.
abstract: British government issues six-month business visa to Chinese artist Ai Weiwei, after initially granting him one for only 20 days, and apologizes for inconvenience; Ai says, however, that he may skip visiting Britain altogether, missing major exhibition of his work at Royal Academy of Arts, if country does not apologize for accusation that he lied about his criminal history on visa application; says country is putting economic interests above human rights issues.

byline.original: By STEVEN ERLANGER and AUSTIN RAMZY
byline.contributor: Steven Erlanger reported from London, and Austin Ramzy from Hong Kong.

lead_paragraph: The turnabout comes after a day of embarrassing criticism over the government’s assertion that the dissident Chinese artist had lied on his application.

headline.main: Reversing Itself, Britain Grants Ai Weiwei a Six-Month Visa
headline.print_headline: Britain Offers Chinese Artist 6-Month Visa After Uproar
